Headline.Para: More to life at SIM than classes

LeadPara.Para: Six in 10 who study full-time at the private school take up activities outside of classroom
Private school students usually focus on getting a degree in the shortest time time possible, but this is not the case at the Singapore Institute of Management (SIM).

TailParas.Para: More than 60 per cent of its 16,500 full-time students take up activities outside the classroom, such as sports, co-curricular activities, internships and exchanges.
To help its students improve their job prospects by nurturing their personal and work skills, SIM is going all out to encourage more of them to participate in activities outside of their classroom.

Mr Lee Kwok Cheong, chief executive officer of SIM Holdings, which runs degree programmes with 12 university partners, said the school surveys employers on what they are looking for in their graduate workers and also came up with the three Rs programme - to build resourcefulness, responsibility and resilience in its students.
He explained the importance of building resilience, or just plain grit.

"Our students don't necessarily have the best positive self-image when they enrol in SIM, which for many of them is the second choice after they fail to get into the local universities. We aim to help them get that confidence, that edge back," he said.
The key to building these other attributes and skills is through out-of-classroom activities, he added.

"We will continue to give students a good academic grounding, but we also offer a variety of student development activities. Besides having fun, students get the opportunity to plan, organise and manage these activities and, in the process, develop organisational and people skills," he said.
Mr Lee said SIM has Project 1095, which is the number of days in three years - the time typically spent by a degree student at SIM.
"The number 1095 is repeated throughout SIM, to remind students to make full use of every day in SIM," he added.

The school also hopes to encourage internships and enable its graduates to land good jobs by organising more career fairs. It used to hold one career fair a year, attended by more than 120 employers. But now it will hold smaller industry-specific fairs through the year.
Traditionally, private school graduates have done less well than those from publicly funded universities.

Six in 10 private school graduates found full-time jobs within six months after completing their studies, according to the graduate employment survey released last November by the Committee for Private Education and SkillsFuture Singapore. Private school graduates drew an average starting monthly pay of $2,550 - more than 20 per cent lower than that of graduates of the six publicly funded universities.
SIM's own yearly survey showed better outcomes - 82.7 per cent of its graduates in 2016 found jobs within six months of completing their degree studies, while the average starting salary was $2,700.
But SIM hopes to further boost the job prospects of its graduates.

Dr Timothy Chan, who heads the student life division, said: "With the increased competition for jobs, we cannot just run degree programmes. We have to offer a vibrant campus environment with platforms for leadership and personal development."
The school offers more than 70 sports and student activity clubs.
SIM accounting and finance student James Ong, 25, has landed a job before his graduation in September.
He said he had "a full student life", going on a global exposure and language immersion programme in Japan, serving as a student leader, doing voluntary work and taking part in in competitions.
Said Mr Ong: "The best part was the internships, especially the one at PwC, which landed me a full-time job."
